Hi Kent,
    Thank you very much for your reply and code.

Warm regards,

c=
haz :)

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kentb" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Chaz,
=
>  
> GetName() was removed in the move to a DSL-style interface with JUnit=
 4. The
> tradeoff was that if we dropped getName(), programmers would be f=
ree to
> subclass from anything for their test classes. I haven't subsequen=
tly used
> this freedom to any good effect, but it seemed like a good idea =
at the time.
>  
> With 4.7 (available from GitHub or the 4.7 snapshot on S=
ourceForge), you can
> use interceptors to capture the test's name. It's ea=
sy, if you already know
> about interceptors that is and you don't waste 15=
 minutes remembering that
> interceptors have to be public and that you sti=
ll have to run with the
> Interceptors runner. They say that memory is the =
second thing to go...
>  
> @RunWith(Interceptors.class)
> public class Nam=
eTest {
>   String name;
>   @Interceptor 
>   public StatementInterceptor =
namer=3D new StatementInterceptor(){
>     @Override
>     public Statement=
 intercept(Statement base, FrameworkMethod method) {
>       name=3D method=
.getName();
>       return base;
>     }
>   };
>   @Test
>   public void f=
unnyName() {
>     assertEquals("funnyName", name);
>   } 
> }
> 
> This su=
ffers from cleverness, but it doesn't get the problem solved without
> an e=
ntire new runner, which was the point of interceptors in the first
> place.=

> 
> Regards,
> 
> Kent
> ________________________________
> 
> From: juni=
t@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of chaz
> Sent: =
Friday, May 08, 2009 8:51 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit]=
 What happened to getName()?
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Hi, 
> I was wondering, is th=
ere a particularly good reason why the most useful
> method getName() was r=
emoved in junit 4.x? Is there another method or way
> for me to get the cur=
rent name of the method executing for reporting
> purposes?
> 
> Thanks,
> =

> chaz
>
